rationale: The Highland Splitfin is now only known to be extant from the Lago Zacapu. Taking in consideration a single location and the worst case scenarios for AOO and EOO, in addition to the given threat scenarios and declines in AOO, EOO, locations, habitats and quality of habitats, the Highland Splitfin is assessed Critically Endangered.
habitat:
This species lives in quiet waters with currents none to slight of lakes, ponds, canals and ditches. The substrates in the habitats are mainly mud, silt, clay, sand, rocks and decaying organic matter. It prefers depths less than 1.3 m. The water is clear to usually turbid or muddy, vegetation is present and dense, mainly green algae, Potamogeton, Eichhornia, Typha and Scirpus. The Laguna de Zacapú is a spring-fed lake, drained by the Río Angulo, which divides in two streams after 20 km. The habitat is 0.5 to 1 m deep and the ground is predominantly of mud which leads to a translucent (greenish) to turbid water. The Highland Splitfin prefers well planted areas, where it is hiding under the aquatic vegetation, including Chara, Potamogeton, Ceratophyllum and green algae (Miller, 2005). Hubbsina turneri is a semi-nocturnal predator feeding from small Crustacea, Bloodworms and Mosquito larvae. It usually hides by day and hunts at dusk and dawn.

The Lago Zacapú is an irregular shaped small lagoon with an extension from the north-west to the south-west, length about 670 m, width about 470 m. In the south-west corner of the lake begins the dammed outlet, extending east-north-east upward over a length of about 800 m and 60 m wide over the whole length. The outlet ends with a southwards bended hook with an extension of 150 x 90 m. After the dam, the affluent of the Canal or Río Angulo begins and merges into it after about 6.5 km. Köck et al. (2014, 2015, 2016 and 2017; M. Köck pers. comm. 2018) found the species in small numbers on two sites of the lagoon in shallow water between dense roots and foliage of willow trees (Salix sp.). The water was, in one place, greenish brown but clear with little current and partly shaded by trees; in the other place, brownish but clear, with little current as well. Other species found at the first spot were Skiffia lermae, Xenotoca variata, Goodea atripinnis, Allotoca zacapuensis and Zoogoneticus quitzeoensis, at the second site the same species except the Zacapú Allotoca. 


The Lago Zacapú is fed by approximately 20 cold water springs (19 °C), which emerge at the southwestern end of the valley of Zacapú, some of which are used for human consumption and recreation (Ramsar Secretariat, Site No.1465, 2004). Also, with the confluence of fish species, migratory birds, plants and endemic amphibians (Ambystoma andersoni), it can be considered as a broad transitional zone, giving it great ecological importance. Two main sections of Lago Zacapú differ, with one of depths between 4 to 6 m, and the other region from 12 to 90 m deep, bedded by soils and alluvium (Ramsar Secretariat, Site No.1465, 2004).
threats: The species has a restricted range and it is threatened in the Lago  Zacapú by pollution, increasing sedimentation and the advance of the  Zacapú town's frontier (Ramsar Secretariat, Site No.1465, 2004). The  Zacapu-lagoon had been once a large cienega (33,500 ha), but has been   drained to provide land for cultivation. It is now a small waterbody of only 33.5 ha in size.
population: The only remaining population, that of Lago Zacapu, is in relatively good condition (O. Domínguez-Domínguez pers. comm. 2018)
range:
The Highland Splitfin is a freshwater fish species endemic to the Mexican federal state of Michoacán. It was historically reported from the endorheic Río Grande de Morelia drainage including the river itself, the Presa Cointzio (type location), the Lago Cuitzeo and some of its affluents and the Laguna Yuriría. It furthermore inhabits the flat area of the former Zacapu paleolake.  In 2013 a population was discovered in a tiny spring in the village of Jesús María, which is an affluent of the Canal Patera, the main source of the Río Angulo at Villa Jiménez, but this spring has dried up in recent years. It now is only found in Lago Zacapu.

A study carried out by Domínguez-Domínguez et al. (2008) found that the Highland Splitfin has disappeared from more than the 65% of its historical range.
useTrade: The Highland Splitfin is not a target species for the ornamental fish trade and not part of human consumption.
conservationActions: No conservation actions targeting Hubbsina turneri are known, but the Zacapú lake is a Ramsar site (No.1465, 2004). The only conservation effort is a monitoring and ex-situ breeding project run by the Laboratorio de Biología Acuatica in Michoacan University, Morelia, Mexico

rationale: In recent surveys, the species was collected at only three sites (three locations), on three different minute Rock Islands, some of which are not protected. It has not been recorded from its type locality (the forested island of Koror) in recent surveys, indicating the vulnerability of this species to habitat degradation and modification of its native lowland forest habitat. Considering the species’ minute area of occupancy, the restricted number of locations from where it is known, and the continuing decline in the quantity and quality of habitat on at least one of the islands where it is currently found, suggests that habitat destruction of native forest could drive the species to extinction in a very short time. The species is therefore listed as Endangered. Site protection for this species is required.
habitat: This species inhabits limestone rock (Rundell 2010). It has <span lang="EN-US">a very unique shell  ornamentation pattern and shape relative to other Palau diplommatinids,  and is the namesake for the Palau islands.
threats: This species is threatened by destruction and modification of its native forests. The species no longer occurs on Koror, its type locality, according to the most recent data (Rundell 2010). Koror is the most heavily populated area of Palau, and has been substantially modified by humans. This suggests that human encroachment has negatively impacted this species.
population: There is no information on population size or trends.
range: This is a land snail endemic to Palau. Historically, the species' range included only the island of Koror (Oreor) (Beddome 1889, Y. Kondo 1936 unpublished data). During surveys in 2007, the species was collected at three sites, on three different minute Rock Islands in Palau (three locations). The species' extent of occurrence is estimated as less than 10 km² and its area of occupancy as less than 2.5 km².
conservationActions: Field work to define the current distribution of this species, as well as research on its population status and trends, is required. Identification of priority sites for species conservation (e.g., key biodiversity areas that include threatened land snails) and reducing the impacts of human activities, especially on the small islands, is also urgently needed. The Palau Conservation Society has been supportive of recent land snail survey work in Palau.

rationale: Ictalurus australis occurs in eastern Mexico from Blanco River to the Pánuco River in southern Veracruz, Mexico. There is inadequate information however to make a direct or indirect assessment of its risk of extincion based on its distribution. More information about the species population size, threats and trends are required to assess it in a category other than Data Deficient.
habitat: I. australis inhabits quiet and slow-flowing waters such as lakes and river pools, as well as slow-current areas near river margins. It is an omnivore catfish that feeds on a wide array of prey, with variable diet throughout ontogeny, including detritus, small invertebrates, and small vertebrates such as fish and even birds (Ceballos et al. 2016, Contreras-MacBeath, pers. comm). The species spawns during spring and beginning of summer, nesting on sand and mud substrates, where both parents protect the eggs (Burgess 1989).
threats: The main threat faced by this species is overfishing, as it is highly desired and heavily harvested by artisanal and commercial fisheries for local consumption. Other threats include habitat modification and water pollution resulting from dam construction and agriculture, respectively. Furthermore, invasive species from the genus Pterygoplichthys may predate on their eggs and negatively affect its populations (Domínguez-Domínguez, pers. comm.).
population: Numerical estimates of population sizes and population trends for Ictalurus australis are unknown. However, it has been reported that the species includes few populations and with ongoing declines due to overfishing and habitat degradation (Ceballos et al. 2016, Domínguez-Domínguez, pers. comm).
range: Ictalurus australis is distributed in the Blanco and Pánuco rivers, southern Veracruz state, eastern Mexico (Ceballos et al. 2016, Eschmeyer et al. 2018).
useTrade: I. australis is primarily harvested and highly desired for human local consumption, with artisanal and commercial fisheries representing the main threat to the survival and persistence of the species (Domínguez-Domínguez, pers. comm.). It is not known to be used in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: The American Fisheries Society Endangered Species Committee lists Ictalurus australis as Threatened (T) due to an imminent danger of becoming Endangered in part or all its distribution range as a result of a decline in population size resulting from present or threatened destruction, modification, or reduction of the taxon’s habitat or range and over-exploitation for commercial, recreational, scientific, or educational purposes including intentional eradication or indirect impacts of fishing (Jelks et al. 2008). Similarly, I. australis is federally listed as Endangered ("En Peligro de Extinción [P]") in the Norma Oficial Mexicana NOM-059-SEMARNAT-2010 (SEMARNAT 2010).

rationale: I. mexicanus is herein categorized as Vulnerable (VU) due to the restricted extent of its geographic distribution (upper Pánuco River, San Luis Potosí, México) coupled with the pervasive threats to the species, such as habitat degradation (resulting from land use changes, pollution, surface water diversion, and ground water extraction) and the impacts of non-native species, including hybridization with blue catfish Ictulurus pricei. The restricted number of locations (1) defined by the main current threats to the species makes it vulnerable to become Critically Endangered (CR) or Extinct (EX) in a very short time.
habitat: Specifics details are unknown for this species. It is encountered in both still and moving water (moderate to swift currents), over rocky or sandy bottoms with no aquatic vegetation; adults are likely to prefer deeper, quieter areas (Miller et al. 2005).
threats: The main threats to the species include habitat modification, water abstraction and pollution, and invasive species in the Pánuco river basin.
population: Ictalurus mexicanus is a very rare species, with a restricted geographic range and very few documented records (Miller et al. 2005, Ceballos et al. 2016). There is virtually no information regarding population sizes and trends.
range: Ictalurus mexicanus is a species endemic of the upper Pánuco River (above Cascada de Tamul), San Luis Potosi, Mexico, Atlantic Slope (Miller et al. 2005). Closely related but undescribed species are reported for a wider geographic extent, including drainages in the states of Querétaro and Hidalgo. For the purpose of this assessment, the geographic distribution is restricted to the population of the upper Pánuco River, San Luis Potosí (Miller et al. 2005).
useTrade: This species is not utilised or traded.
conservationActions: In Mexico, Ictalurus mexicanus is federally listed as threatened [“Amenazado” (A)] in the Norma Oficial Mexicana NOM-059-SEMARNAT-2010 (SEMARNAT 2010), a compendium of species or populations of wild flora and fauna at risk in Mexican territory. The category “A” of the NOM-059-SEMARNAT-2010 implies a high risk of extinction in the short- and medium-term if the current threats to the species persist. A compendium of the conservation status of imperiled North American freshwater and diadromous fishes (Jelks et al. 2008) lists I. mexicanus as Vulnerable (V). Besides being included in the above mentioned lists, there are no official programs for the conservation of this species (Ceballos et al. 2016).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because although the extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, and probably population size are not very large (perhaps below the thresholds for Vulnerable), the species is represented by a large number of subpopulations and locations, and the trend over the past 10 years or three generations appears to be relatively stable.
habitat: This bass typically occurs rocky and sandy pools of creeks and small to medium rivers (Page and Burr 2011), with moderate to low gradient, clear to often moderately turbid warm water, and rock, gravel, sand, and silt substrates. It is most common in clearer, firmer bottomed streams; occurrence over soft substrates is most typical in the lower Piedmont and upper Coastal Plain. Rarely is it found naturally in impoundments. In the upper Coastal Plain, it occupies stained flowing waters lined with swamps (Burkhead and Jenkins 1991). In the upper Piedmont, adults and large juveniles are in deep runs, in the current-swept heads of pools, and sometimes in the calm parts of pools (Burkhead and Jenkins 1991). The young probably occur well under cover in calm water (Burkhead and Jenkins 1991). In hatchery ponds, nests were constructed and guarded by males in shallow water on gravel; sand and muck substrates were avoided.
threats: Decline of this species is attributed to impoundment, pollution, competition with introduced populations of rock bass (A. rupestris), and adverse spring stream conditions in certain years (Petrimoulx 1983). Burkhead and Jenkins (1991) identified siltation as the probable cause of decline, together with competition and introgressive hybridization with the introduced rock bass in the upper Roanoke River drainage.
population:
This species is represented by several dozen occurrences (subpopulations) (Menhinick 1991, Jenkins and Burkhead 1994).

Total adult population size is unknown. This bass is rare or uncommon in Virginia (Burkhead and Jenkins 1991). In North Carolina, it is moderately widespread and occurs over several hundred stream miles in Tar and Neuse systems (H. LeGrand pers. comm., 1997); but it is usually uncommon to rare even in areas known to harbor populations (Braswell 1991).

Trend over the past 10 years or three generations is uncertain but probably relatively stable or slowly declining. Jelks et al. (2008) indicated that this species had the same status (Vulnerable) in 2008 as it did in 1989, seemingly meaning that it had been relatively stable over that period.
range: Range includes the Chowan, Roanoke, Tar, Neuse, and Cape Fear river drainages, Virginia and North Carolina (Menhinick 1991, Jenkins and Burkhead 1994, Page and Burr 2011). This bass occupies the Valley and Ridge, Piedmont, and upper Coastal Plain provinces (also the fringes of the Blue Ridge). This species is apparently extirpated from the extreme upper Roanoke system (Jenkins and Burkhead 1994). Roanoke bass have been stocked n the upper and lower James and middle New drainages in Virginia and in North Carolina impoundments and streams, but these stockings did not establish extant populations (McBride et al. 1980, Jenkins and Burkhead 1994).
conservationActions: This species would benefit from habitat restoration, improved habitat protection and management, and better information on distribution, abundance, population trend, and threats.

rationale: This species is only known from the historical record from 1898. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: No information about habitat and ecology of this species is available.
threats: No information is available about threats to this species.
range: This species is only known from the type specimen that was recorded originally in 1898 from Sumatra (Indonesia) although the exact locality was not provided.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized or traded.
conservationActions: Research is needed to establish the current distribution, habitat and threats to this species.

rationale:
The Balsas Splitfin inhabits the Upper Río Coahuayana basin and northern affluents of the Río Balsas from the Río Atoyac in the east to the Río Grande in the west. The species is threatened by water pollution through agriculture and wastewater from cities and towns, by water overexploitation and competition through non-native species. Though the species is facing declines and disappeared from some habitats, it still can be found in a wide range over five federal states. 

With an estimated AOO of 7,000km² and EOO of 80,000km² as well as about 25 locations, the Balsas Splitfin does not meet any tresholds for assigning a threat status, therefore it is assessed of Least Concern.
habitat:
Ilyodon whitei is a freshwater species that occupies permanent rivers and also small side streams. The Rio Balsas is a major river system, the basin of which flows through the states of Puebla, Morelos, Guerrero, and Mexico. The river flows through the Sierra Madre del Sur and Franja Volcanica Transmexicana, and empties into the Pacific Ocean at Mangrove Point, adjacent to the city of Lázaro Cárdenas, Michoacán. Several rapids along the course of the Balsas River limit its navigability and thus the river has been largely used for generation of hydroelectric power, flood control and irrigation. 

The habitats are pools and riffles of clear to turbid streams, over substrates of sand, silt, mud, gravel, rocks and boulders. The currents are usually slight to swift. Vegetation can be absent or made of green algae, Potamogeton and Ceratophyllum. The preferred depth is less than 1.3m (Miller, 2005).

Observations of Köck et al. in March 2016 in the Río Contla about 100m N of the Highway 110 bridge at Contla revealed a very shallow habitat with water depths less than 30cm and a width of 3 to 4 metres, in the rainy season reaching up a width of about 8m inferred from the existing pebbly shore. The habitat was structured with few big rocks and boulders in the middle of the current and a lot of gravel of different sizes, mud, sand and silt. Few patches of submerse vegetation (Characeae) could be seen in the more quiet parts of the creek. The current was mainly swift, the water clear. The water parametres about noon were: pH 7.6, carbonate hardness 3°, total hardness 7°, water temperature 22°C. The quantity of urban waste was moderate, a discharge of polluted water close to the bridge raised the pH to 8.6 and led to the occurence of nitrite (1mg/l) and nitrate (25mg/l) that were absent above the discharge pipe. The Balsas Splitfin (dominant species, about 90% of the total number of fish) was associated with Allodontichthys tamazulae and its congener Allodontichthys hubbsi, Poeclia butleri and Tilapias (species not determined). The top predator seemed to be Dobsonfly larvae (subfamily Corydalinae, family Corydalidae) with about 10 - 12cm total length that could be seen hunting successfully two times in 30 min. 

The Río Tamazula east of Tamazula de Giordano has a width of 5 to 10m with a depth down to about 50cm. The bottom is comprised of big rocks and boulders, gravel, silt, mud and sand. The water in March 2016 was swift to torrential, depending on ground and width, and clear to murky. The water parametres were similar to the ones from the Río Contla. The species was associated with the same fish as in its affluent, additionally could be found a few Xenotoca lyonsi. The embankment was comprised by small trees (probably Salix), reed and few herbaceous riparian plants; the main sections of the riverbank were free of vegetation. The quantity of urban waste was moderate, very close were viscous remains of burnt sugar cane that would be washed in the river when raining.

The Presa Santa Catarina has an extension of 300 x 100-180m, the average depth couldn't be ascertained, but might be deeper than 1.5m. During a survey in 2017, Köck et al. documented this species from the upper part of the Presa. Here a narrow path over a wall dams the spring creek up to a 20 x 30m shallow pool and separates it from the rest of the Presa with a passage in the middle. Another wall is on top of this pool, leavig a passage for the moderatly fast flowing creek. Fish could be found on both sides of this little dam. The water was about 50cm deep, the ground made up of silt, mud and sand, with almost evenly distributed rocks and boulders. Those rocks were densily covered with green filamentous and short brown algae and aufwuchs. The shore was partly made up of riparian grass, partly building up dense vegetation growing in the shallow water or hanging over the surface. The habitat was partly shaded by huge willow trees (Salix sp.). Ilyodon whitei was mainly hiding between the rocks or more often in the vegetation. The only other fish at this collection site was another Goodeid species, Allotoca catarinae. The Presa itself is bordered by walls forming a steep bank on the left side and a sandy-grassy shallow beach on the right one, everything partly shaded by trees. The water parametres taken in March 2017 were: Water temperature; 17.4°C, pH: 7.25, conductivity: 1,108μS.

Pictures of habitats as attachments.
threats: The Balsas Splitfin is mainly threatened by water pollution, caused by agriculture and wastewater discharges from towns and cities, furthermore from water withdrawal for domestic use and agriculture and by competition through non-native fish, mainly Tilapia and Poeciliids.
population:
Many populations of the Balsas Splitfin have declined or disappeared over the last 25 years, largely because of predation by or competition from non-native fish species (e.g., Contreras-MacBeath et al., 1998). Non-native species now dominate many areas of the Balsas River basin (Lyons, 2011). 

Mercado-Silva surveyed several rivers in the state of Morelos from 2016-2017. Here his results: "The Balsas Splitfin historically had a relatively widespread distribution in the State of Morelos. From museum records of the university of Morelos, they are known from 35 sites in the following rivers: Arroyo Ahuehuello (State of Puebla), Río Nexapa (State of Puebla), Arroyo Los Sabinos, Atotonilco and Jantetelco lakes, Río Yautepec, Río Amacuzac, Las Pilas Spring, Río Amacuzac, Río Apatlaco, Río Atoyac, Río Barranca de Todos los Santos, Río Cuautla and Río Chalma. Many of these sites have been sampled multiple times since 1985 when the Museum started tracking sampling efforts.  During 2016 -  2017 field trips were made to the following watersheds in the Balsas Basin: Amacuzac, Apatlaco, Cuautla, and Yautepec. In all sites, we captured approximately 330 individuals of Ilyodon whitei. The number of individuals captured varied between 2 – 103. This species once widespread and locally common throughout its range has seen its stocks in the State of Morelos suffer from excessive water withdrawals and have quite likely been affected by the numerous invasive fishes found in lotic systems throughout the state." Lyons (pers. comm., 2018) surveyed in 2017 the Río Atoyac, the easternmost habitat of this species but could only find few specimens. 

Köck et al. (2016) surveyed the Río Tamazula E of Tamazula de Giordano and the Río Contla. In both river, the Balsas Splitfin was numerous. In the Río Contla, it could be seen in hundreds in very shallow water of gravel and rocks,
range:
The Balsas Splitfin is a freshwater species endemic to the Mexican federal states of Michoacán, Mexico, Morelos, Guerrero and Pueblo. It is known from the upper Río Coahuayana drainage (sections Río Tamazula and Tuxpán) and affluents, and from most of the northern reaches of the Río Balsas, starting in the E with the ríos Atoyac, Amacuzac, Tepecuacuilco and Cocula in the Eastern Río Balsas basin, then the ríos Oxtotitlán, Palos Altos, Cutzamala, the arroyos San Lucas and Grande and the Río Chiquito in the Central Río Balsas basin, and finally the Río Grande, western Río Balsas basin.  

In 2008, an estimation resulted in the disappearance of the Balsas Splitfin from nearly 15% of its historical range (Domínguez-Domínguez et al., 2008).

The underlined names are the ones officially used by the Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía (http://antares.inegi.org.mx); nevertheless, other ones might be more often in use or better known and therefore prefered.
useTrade: Ilyodon whitei is neither part of human consumption nor a target species for the ornamental fish trade.
conservationActions: No conservation actions for Ilyodon whitei are known.

rationale: This species was most recently collected in only a single locality on the island of Peleliu in Palau. This species is listed as Critically Endangered (Possibly Extinct) due to its very narrow geographic range, being known from only one location, and because of the observed decline in the quality and extent of the species' habitat. Further research is urgently recommended to determine whether or not this species is still extant in Palau.
habitat: This species of snail is ground-dwelling and has been recorded from moist lowland forest.
threats: This species is threatened by alteration of its lowland forest habitat. Many activities have resulted in forest alteration on Peleliu in the last 100-200 years, including mining activities, human habitation, construction of an airstrip and the burning of much of the vegetation on the island during one of the bloodiest battles of World War II (Hinz 1995, Crombie and Pregill 1999). However, many Palau endemic land snails are still extant on Peleliu, so it is unclear why the area of occupancy of  this species has been so severely restricted. Much vegetation has recovered since WWII, but it is possible that unlike some other endemic species, it may have depended on certain plants or trees that are now rare or extinct on Peleliu. Recent habitat modifications could also be impacting this species. Additional surveys on the island and investigations into this species’ ecology are needed to determine whether this species is indeed extinct in Palau.
population: There is no information available on this species' population size or trends.
range: The geographic range of this species is less than 12 km2 and its area of occupancy is much less than this, based on the recovery of a single dead specimen from one point locality in 2003 (Rundell 2005, 2010). The species has not been collected alive anywhere in Palau since then. Extensive surveys have been carried out on most islands of Palau in 2003, 2005 and 2007 (Rundell 2010). Historically, there would have been suitable vegetation on much of Peleliu, however, this island has been subject to substantial modification of the vegetation in the last 100-200 years, from mining activities, human habitation, construction of an airstrip and burning of much of the vegetation on the island during one of the bloodiest battles of World War II - U.S. Operation Stalemate, Peleliu Invasion, 1944 (Hinz 1995, Crombie and Pregill 1999).
conservationActions: Field work is urgently required to define this species' current distribution, population status and trend. Identification of priority sites for species conservation, such as key biodiversity areas, as well as reducing the impacts of human activities, is also needed. Additional surveys on Peleliu and investigations into this species’ ecology are needed to determine whether this species is indeed extinct in Palau, and if so, why it might have gone extinct. The Palau Conservation Society has been supportive of recent land snail survey work in Palau.

rationale: Lagocephalus gloveri is distributed from the Andaman Sea east to Indonesia, north to southern Japan, including the Yellow and Bohai seas, and can be found at depths ranging from zero to 100 metres. It is common in parts of its range. Adults inhabit the continental shelf over sandy or muddy bottoms, and juveniles can be found in estuaries. Unpublished data indicate that this species may be a junior synonym of Lagocephalus cheesmani, and there is taxonomic confusion in several species of the genus including L. cheesemanii, L. gloveri, L. spadiceus and L. wheeleri. Lagocephalus gloveri is a popular food fish in China, Taiwan and Japan. There is little species-specific population information available. This species is non-toxic and safe for consumption as processed and fresh fish product. It appears to be landed in large quantities in parts of its range, but does not appear to be particularly valuable. Based on population trends seen in other species of commercially important pufferfishes it is inferred that this species is undergoing population declines in parts of its range. It is also likely to be impacted by coastal habitat degradation, particularly near estuaries and river mouths. Suspected population declines from exploitation and habitat degradation are not quantifiable and therefore do not meet the thresholds for a threatened category. Pending clarification concerning this species' distribution and population status, this species is assessed as Data Deficient. The taxonomy of this and several other species of Lagocephalus remains unresolved.
habitat:
Lagocephalus gloveri is a tropical species found at depths ranging from 0-100 m. Adults inhabit the continental shelf where they are found over sandy or muddy bottoms. Juveniles can be found in estuaries (Matsuura and Liu pers comm. 2011). Lagocephalus gloveri feeds on molluscs, crustaceans and fishes. It is most similar to L. spadiceus and L. guentheri in appearance (Matsuura et al. 2011).

Puffers of the genus Lagocephalus are globally distributed in warm shallow waters, however classification at the species level in Lagocephalus has not yet been studied in depth, causing confusion in the status of several species including L. cheesemanii, L. gloveri, L. spadiceus, and L. wheeleri (Matsuura et al. 2011).

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats:
Pufferfish fishery
Lagocephalus gloveri is impacted by pufferfish fisheries in parts of its range. In Japan, Pufferfish landings have declined since the early 1990s. Concern about the fishery centers on the most valuable and preferred species, Takifugu rubripes, which, as of 2010, was considered depleted in Japan. Landings of T. rubripes in Japan had declined to 5% of annual landings in 1987. Landings of "other pufferfish", a category which includes L. gloveri, were maximized after the decline in T. rubripes landings. These "other pufferfish" have declined from a peak of roughly 400 tonnes in 1999 to less than 100 tonnes in 2007, a decline of roughly 75%. Declines in landings have been attributed to the effects of highly-effective long-line fishing (Kawata 2012).

Fishery-dependent data from China showed declines in catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) of L. gloveri from 2001 to 2003, however this data may represent several species of this genus. In the Zhoushan Islands L. gloveri contributed about 15% of the total salted/dried tetraodontiform fish products found in markets. In northern Taiwan, L. gloveri accounted for 80% of the tetraodontiform fish capture volume (uncited/unpublished data).

Habitat degradation
Furthermore, habitat degradation is occurring in many coastal areas within this species' range, particularly near river mouths (J. Liu pers. comm. 2011). In the semi-enclosed regions of the North Bohai and Yellow Seas, large amounts of industrial and municipal effluents containing heavy metals, particularly arsenic, have been implicated in the deterioration of coastal environments (Luo et al. 2010). Heavy metals have also been implicated in the degradation of the heavily populated and industrialized Pearl River delta region in southern China (Cheung et al. 2003). In the Gulf of Thailand, coastal habitat degradation has resulted from pollution, primarily from untreated municipal and industrial waste water, as well as a rapid decrease in mangrove forests, coral reefs, and fisheries resources (Cheevaporn and Menasveta 2003).
population:
Lagacephalus gloveri is common and can be locally abundant (K. Matsuura and L. Jing pers. comm. 2011). It is common in Taiwan (Shao pers. comm. 2011) and in the east China Sea (M. Liu and J. Liu pers. comm. 2011). Lagocephalus gloveri is a component of the pufferfish trade in east Asia, where it trades under the name sabafugu. It has also been associated with the name "kuro-sabafugu".

In Japan Pufferfish landings have declined since the early 1990s. Landings of "other pufferfish", a category which includes L. gloveri, were maximized after the decline T. rubripes landings. These "other pufferfish" have declined from a peak of roughly 400 tonnes in 1999 to less than 100 tonnes in 2007, a decline of roughly 75%. Declines in pufferfish have been attributed to the effects of highly-effective long-line fishing (Kawata 2012). The percent contribution of L. gloveri to the category "other pufferfish" is unknown.

Fishery-dependent data from China showed declines in catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) of L. gloveri from 2001 to 2003, however these data may represent several species of this genus. The catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) was: 0.88 t/day/boat in 2001, 1.13 t/day/boat in 2002, and 0.72 t/day/boat in 2003 (unpublished data)

Although there is currently no reliable species-specific information concerning the population status of L. gloveri, and population trends could not be quantified, it is inferred that this species undergoing localized declines in parts of its range where it is harvested commercially.

Specimens of L. gloveri are common in museum collections. This species is represented by at least 104 lots in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 30 April 2012).
range: Lagocephalus gloveri is known from the Andaman Sea east to Indonesia, north to southern Japan (Shizuoka Prefecture,West Pacific). It is also found on the coasts of the South China Sea, East China Sea, Yellow Sea and Bohai Sea (M. Liu and L. Jing pers. comm. 2011, Su and Li 2002). The record of this species from eastern Australia needs to be revised based on ongoing taxonomic work on L. cheesemani (K. Matsuura pers. comm. 2011). It has been recorded at depths ranging from 1-100 m.
useTrade: Lagocephalus gloveri is widely utilized in the dry fish market through much of east Asia (Chen et al. 2003). This species and L. spadiceus are considered non-toxic, and are approved for use in Taiwan for the dry fish market (Wu et al. 2008). Catch statistics for this species and L. spadiceus are lumped together as "sabafugu" in Japan (Kawata 2012). In Japan, the muscle, skin, and male gonad are consumed (Noguchi and Arakawa 2008).
conservationActions:
Fisheries
Lagocephalus gloveri is a component of the pufferfish fishery in East Asia. While no species-specific regulations are known to be in place for L. gloveri, management efforts targeting the fishery as a whole are likely to positively impact this species. On a regional scale, the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea in 1999 resulted in fisheries agreements reached between Japan, South Korea, and China. These agreements restructured fishery management by giving coastal countries the ability to regulate foreign fishing vessels. The Fisheries Agency of Japan announced the Plan for Rebuilding Puffer Resources in April 2005, which led to the establishment of an off-fishing season, restriction on minimum body size, improvements to fishing grounds, and other measures. The plan was extended past 2010 to 2012 due to the failure of L. gloveri to recover (Kawata 2012).

Other conservation measures
There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for L. gloveri, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas.
